explanation:
1) SHA1CircularShift
   - The function (or macro) is called repeatedly from inside the for-loop bodies. MISRA's requirement treats the behaviour of the loop body as including called functions; you must inspect SHA1CircularShift to ensure it has no persistent side effects (does not modify the loop counter 'i' or any object used in the for-loop clauses) and that it does not access or modify objects used in the loop control expressions. If SHA1CircularShift is a macro, check for multiple evaluation of arguments that could introduce side effects.

2) struct SHA1Context (complete definition)
   - The function reads and updates members of context (message_block, intermediate_hash, message_block_index). You must see the types and qualifiers of these members (e.g. whether message_block is an array of uint8_t/volatile, whether intermediate_hash is an array, whether message_block_index is volatile or has special semantics). MISRA forbids the second clause to use objects modified in the loop body and forbids side effects on objects used in clauses; the full struct definition lets you verify that no loop clause depends on fields that are modified in the body and whether accesses could have hidden side effects.

3) stdint typedefs (uint32_t, uint8_t or equivalent)
   - Knowing the underlying typedefs ensures correct understanding of types used for loop counter interactions and expressions (e.g. integer promotions, signedness). Also needed if any macro or function uses type-dependent behaviour that could affect whether loop clauses use objects modified by the body.

Notes: No other external symbols (callers SHA1PadMessage / SHA1Input) are required to decide whether the for loops in SHA1ProcessMessageBlock are well-formed under MISRA C — the primary concerns are whether the loop counter 'i' is the only counter and whether called code (SHA1CircularShift) or accessed context members introduce side effects on objects used in the for clauses.
